title: Support perspective projections with shear

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

body:
## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill?

The ability to create a camera with a sheared projection matrix is important for a number of use cases:
* Multi-monitor rendering. Imagine a 3x3 display of monitors, each being rendered by a separate processor, but the 3d scene spans the entire array. Now say you want to render the top-left monitor: the camera position is still centered on the middle monitor, the view frustum for the top left monitor is "sheared".
* Efficient rendering of portals - generally a portal will only want to render a small portion of the window (the 2d bounding box of the portal) to the render target, rather than rendering the entire screen, which would be slow.

## What solution would you like?

The [setViewOffset()](https://threejs.org/docs/#api/en/cameras/PerspectiveCamera.setViewOffset) API in three.js is fairly simple. It accepts six parameters:

* fullWidth — full width of multiview setup
* fullHeight — full height of multiview setup
* x — horizontal offset of subcamera
* y — vertical offset of subcamera
* width — width of subcamera
* height — height of subcamera

All this does is adjust the perspective projection, and the corresponding view frustum, to render a rectangular subregion of the normal frustum. This is not the same as a clip rect, the subregion is "spread" over the entire viewport rect.

While it's possible that this feature already exists, I could not find it. I would expect that if it did exist, it would be a property of either Camera, Camera3DBundle, or ProjectionMatrix, but I could find nothing in those types relevant to this.

## What alternative(s) have you considered?

I can't think of a workaround for this, other than rendering to a very large render target and then cutting out a small piece of it, which would destroy performance.
